awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Harvesting strawberry using delta robots
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I project is to enhance scientific and technological understanding in selective harvesting of high-value crops such as strawberry. The innovation proposed here will be a key component in creating a compact economically viable autonomous strawberry harvesting robot. The technology developed in this project will help address the farming labor shortage which is experienced by farmers more and more each year. Agricultural robotics market is estimated to be $11.9 billion by 2026. Providing autonomous harvesting robots will enable farmers to grow more crops with less business risks related to manual labor shortages and will ensure that US farmers remain competitive, while creating more skilled, highly paid jobs.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop critical technologies for delicate selective harvesting of fragile crops such as strawberries at a competitive pace. Recent advancements in computer vision object detection and three-dimensional scene reconstruction will be used to create near real-time operational scenes. Those scenes will be used to detect ripe berries, create a movement path and navigate the fast and precise robot arm for harvesting the berries without damaging fruits while avoiding obstacles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project successfully advanced fruit picking robots technologies enabling economically viable strawberry harvesting with low fruit damage. Compact strawberry harvesting prototype has been developed which uses machine vision to navigate a delta robot with a specially designed end-effector to harvest berries in a complex strawberry bush system.

This project innovations include: (1) near real time 3D scene reconstruction hardware and software complex, which provides a high-precision map of the strawberry bushes; (2) near real time 3D point cloud path finding software for the delta robot and the end-effector; (3) a specially designed end-effector, which allows picking strawberry fruits with minimal damage to them; and (4) a hand-eye coordination system, enabling high precision scene manipulations without expensive calibration hardware. The prototype built using those innovations has successfully shown that high-precision strawberry harvesting is technologically possible, enabling the future of fully automated harvesting robots.

The US farming industry is experiencing an ever-increasing labor shortage. Crops such as various fruits, vegetables, and nuts, require manual harvesting due to their delicate nature. This makes growing them highly dependable on a reliable work force. The broader impacts of this project are the ability to automate harvesting of the produce, which is currently harvested only manually, reducing the need for tedious work, alleviating the manual labor shortages, and reducing the corresponding farming risks.

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2024
Modified by: Mikhail Pranovich
